**Your challenge:** What do you think the word **"Bonjour"** means in English?

## ğŸ“‹ Introduction

**Did you guess A?** You're absolutely right!

The word **"Bonjour"** [bÉ”ÌƒÊ’uÊ] means **"Hello"** or **"Good morning"** in English!

**Important note:** "Bonjour" is just the greeting word itself. When the baker says "Bonjour", they're saying "Hello" - they're not necessarily saying a whole sentence like "Welcome to my bakery". It's just the French way to greet someone, just like you'd say "Hi" or "Hello" in English!

This is probably the most important French word you'll ever learn. You'll use it EVERY SINGLE DAY in Belgium!

Welcome to your very first French lesson! 

You're about to learn something super useful: how to introduce yourself in French. Why does this matter? Well, imagine walking into a Belgian bakery, meeting your neighbors, or joining an expat event in Brussels. You'll want to say "hello" and tell people who you are, right? That's exactly what we're going to master today!

**What you will learn today:**

**Why this matters in Belgium:**

When in doubt, a handshake is always appropriate.

**Practical tip:** Watch what Belgians do around you! In professional contexts, always start with a handshake. Most Belgians are understanding if you're not sure about other forms of greeting!

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** "J'aime le chocolat" vs "J'aime chocolat" (missing article) âŒ

**Mistake 2:** "Je n'aime pas le chocolat" - forgetting "pas" âŒ

**If you're struggling with "aimer" conjugation:**

## ğŸ“š Vocabulary: Essential Words

### ğŸ—£ï¸ Useful Expressions for Daily Life

**These expressions will help you describe things!** ğŸ¤

- **C'est...** [sÉ›] : It is... / This is...

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** Forgetting gender agreement with colors: "Une voiture rouge" (correct) vs "Une voiture rouge" if masculine âŒ  
**Correct:** Colors agree with the noun: "Une voiture rouge" (feminine), "Un livre rouge" (masculine) âœ…  
**Why:** Most colors agree with gender. "Rouge" stays the same for both, but some change: "blanc/blanche", "vert/verte", etc.

**Mistake 2:** Capitalizing colors âŒ  
**Correct:** "rouge", "bleu", "vert" (not "Rouge", "Bleu") âœ…  
**Why:** Colors are NOT capitalized in French (unlike in some languages). Only capitalize at the start of a sentence.

**Mistake 3:** "C'est une voiture rouge" vs "Elle est rouge" confusion âŒ  
**Correct:** Both work, but "C'est une voiture rouge" (It's a red car) or "Elle est rouge" (It is red) âœ…  
**Why:** You can describe with "C'est [noun] [color]" or "Il/Elle est [color]". Both are correct, but structure is different.

**Mistake 4:** Using "de" before colors: "Une voiture de rouge" âŒ  
**Correct:** "Une voiture rouge" (no preposition) âœ…  
**Why:** Colors come directly after the noun, no preposition needed. "Une voiture rouge" not "Une voiture de rouge".

## ğŸ“– Grammar: Describing with Adjectives

### Adjective Agreement (Masculine/Feminine)

**Masculine examples:**

**Feminine examples:**
- **une voiture rouge** [yn vwatyÊ ÊuÊ’] = "a red car" (rouge stays the same)
- **une voiture bleue** [yn vwatyÊ blÃ¸] = "a blue car" (bleu â†’ bleue)

**ğŸ’¡ Important:** Some colors don't change (rouge, jaune, marron, orange, rose), but most do!

### Using "C'est" vs "Il est" / "Elle est"

**Use "C'est" for:**
- General descriptions: **C'est beau.** [sÉ› bo] = "It's beautiful."
- Objects: **C'est grand.** [sÉ› gÊÉ‘Ìƒ] = "It's big."
- Colors: **C'est rouge.** [sÉ› ÊuÊ’] = "It's red."

**Use "Il est" / "Elle est" for:**

- Specific objects (with article): **La voiture est rouge.** [la vwatyÊ É› ÊuÊ’] = "The car is red."

**ğŸ’¡ Memory trick:** "C'est" = "It is" (general), "Il/Elle est" = "He/She/It is" (specific)

### Describing with Colors

**Pattern:** "C'est [color]" or "[Noun] est [color]"

- **La voiture est bleue.** [la vwatyÊ É› blÃ¸] = "The car is blue."
- **Le drapeau est rouge, jaune et noir.** [lÉ™ dÊapo É› ÊuÊ’ Ê’on e nwaÊ] = "The flag is red, yellow, and black."

**ğŸ’¡ Note:** Use "et" (and) to connect colors: "rouge et bleu" (red and blue)

## Troubleshooting: Having Trouble?

**If you're struggling with color vocabulary:**
- Learn 5-6 basic colors first: rouge, bleu, vert, jaune, noir, blanc
- Practice saying each color 10 times until they're automatic
- Practice describing objects you see: "C'est rouge", "C'est bleu"
- Don't try to learn all colors at once - build gradually

**If gender agreement with colors confuses you:**
- Most colors stay the same: rouge (m/f), bleu (m/f), jaune (m/f), noir (m/f)
- Some change: blanc/blanche, vert/verte, noir/noire (sometimes)
- Practice pattern: "Un [object] [color]", "Une [object] [color]"
- Start with colors that don't change, then add others gradually

**If describing objects is difficult:**
- Start simple: "C'est [color]" (It's [color])
- Then add noun: "C'est un [object] [color]" (It's a [color] [object])
- Practice with objects around you daily
- Don't worry about perfect grammar at first - focus on communicating

**Still stuck?** Colors are very practical vocabulary. Focus on mastering 5-6 basic colors and practice describing things you see daily. It gets easier with practice!

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

**Before we dive into grammar, watch out for these common mistakes:**

**Mistake 1:** Forgetting to use the infinitive after "aimer": "J'aime lis" âŒ  
**Correct:** "J'aime lire" (I like to read) âœ…  
**Why:** After "aimer", "adorer", "prÃ©fÃ©rer", always use the infinitive form of the verb (lire, voyager, faire), not the conjugated form.

**Mistake 2:** Using "Je aime" instead of "J'aime" âŒ  
**Correct:** "J'aime" (the "e" is dropped before a vowel) âœ…  
**Why:** When "je" is followed by a word starting with a vowel, drop the "e" and add an apostrophe: "J'aime" not "Je aime".

**Mistake 3:** Confusing "aimer" and "aimer bien": "J'aime bien lire" for simple "I like" âŒ
